There is additional guidance throughout the questionnaire. However, if you require support then please contact us on 0300 1234 931 or via email at surveys@ons.gov.uk.

list: This survey is conducted by the Office for National Statistics on behalf of the Department of Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy (BEIS).

BEIS, as the department responsible for the energy industries, uses the information to calculate industrial fuel prices. This is used to inform energy prices policy and used by industry to benchmark and help with negotiation of their energy costs.
Data should relate to sites within the UK.
You can provide informed estimates if actual figures are not available.
We will treat your data securely and confidentially.

contents.description: Fuel oils are the heavier residuals from the refining process. Fuel oils are used for fuel in furnaces and boilers for heating, metallurgic operation and industrial power plants.

The heavier grades of fuel oils require some form of pre-heating before being burned in all situations. These are typically viscous and tar-like and formed from the remnants of the process to make higher quality petroleum products.

question.title: For the reporting period, what was the net calorific value of coal purchased by your business?

definitions.title: What we mean by 'net calorific value'

contents.description: Calorific value represents the amount of heat or energy within a given volume of gas. There can potentially be variations over time or regionally in the quality of natural gas that would affect this.

Gross Calorific Value (GCV) is the amount of heat released by the complete combustion of a unit of natural gas. Net Calorific Value (NCV) is determined by subtracting the heat of vaporisation of the water vapour from this value.

contents.description: This section asks for information about quantity and cost of gas purchased by your business both under an interruptible contract and under a firm contract.
Firm gas contracts are where the gas supply has been guaranteed as uninterruptible by the supplier and customer.
Interruptible gas contracts are where the gas supply may be interrupted by the supplier to manage system demands, in accordance with certain conditions as contracted.
